title: When will be the number of COVID-19 Hospitalizations in the state of Texas for a single day next be 2,500 or lower?
preds: Barring some strange reporting issue where it dips for a day looks to be clearly not before October 4.
Above 3,200 for six of the last seven days.

Very stable at around 3200 patients. Would take something extraordinary for numbers to drop with 100 patients a day now. I think there is less than 1/200 chance of that so going with 100% on the last bin. 14 Sep-4 Oct: -7
>4 Oct: +7
Still at 3200 in hospitals today and this has remained fairly level.

In the last 14 days the number is stable around 3.2K COVID-19 Hospitalizations and no indicator shows that this is going to change soon to the better. The contrary is true: The testing positivity rate is going up. [1] https://txdshs.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/0d8bdf9be927459d9cb11b9eaef6101f

We are clearly not going to pursue anything like an elimination strategy in most places in the US. In TX that means hospitalizations will remain elevated for a long time, especially as case growth has, at best, leveled out and may increase again.
Giving up. I don´t understand the reasons for it, but it´s obvious.

Bottomed out on 9/19 at 3,081.
Now at 3,204.
Barring a sudden drop, 2,500 by 10/4 is very unlikely.
Hospitalizations appear to be ticking back up.

Largely stagnant around 3200 with a week and a half left until the final bucket is reached. Dropping to 2500 would require a daily decrease around 90, which is significantly greater than recent trends (even before the plateau). With cases trending up again nationwide it seems unlikely that this mark will be reached by October 4th, though it is not necessarily impossible.
Recent data flatlining has caused me to reconsider the rate at which I assumed hospitalizations would decrease initially. Based on this, I am largely increasing the probability in the final bucket
With less than two weeks to go and the stabilisation of the number of confirmed COVID-19 patients, it's looking very unlikely the number will drop below 2500 before October 4th.
Weekly model update on latest data -- uptick in hospitalizations and raw cases which should lead more hospitalizations in the period to October 4
the crowd has changed pretty quickly on this one. I'll watch this closely over the next few days, but things are trending the way I originally expected (as per my previous comments).
Updating for 9/23. It looks like the hospitalization data has been plateau for a week. The positivity rate has been dropping steadily, and will most likely to drop below 4% after Oct 4th.

Pushing further oput after seeing two consecuutive upticks folllowed by todays drop of only 6 cases. Hospitalizations would have to decrease by an average of ~2.5% per day until this question closes. Over the past month, cases have decreased at a rate of less than 1.5% and this rate has been decreasing over the course of the last two weeks. The chance of this trend not only reversing, but increasing back to the level of -2.5% per day is vanishingly small, especially as covid cases in the state stabilize.
Paradigm shift for me. The backside of the curve is not monotonic.

As previously mentioned, my strategy is now to decrease the 4th bucket of 2.7 / day when the decrease rate is less than the one needed to get to 2500 on October 4. Given the data of the last 4 days, I can decrease 10.8~11% the 4 th bucket. That increase the note before 4 October from 65 to 76%.
Increase in texas cases make the <10/4 scenario even less likely than before.
Hospitalizations going up, I think I was overconfident in my flawed simulations during earlier periods.

Increasing probability on last bucket since hospitalization curve has increased over the past 2 days. Since we are so close to the expiry (only ~10 days away), I will focus more on the active daily changes as opposed to TS analysis.

No clue at all, why hospitalization numbers are increasing several days in a row, while all other numbers look okay. Have I mentioned yet, that Covid-19 are to be avoided, if you prefer less work and frustration?
Clearly seem to be plateauing at 3000 hospitalizations. Way off the 2500 mark.

Second straight day of increases. Highest level since 9/16.
If rate of decrease next 13 days matches the last 13, that puts the number at 2,854 on 10/4.
Hospitalizations have increased for the third day in the row. With cases also increasing, it is hard to imagine that hospitalizations will fall sufficiently to reach this threshold.
Cases are leveling off in Texas already and it's looking very unlikely that hospitalizations drop down below 2500 in the next couple weeks.
reran with new data. upper and lower bounds are 28 and 19 days. middle is 22. keeping slight chance of early bucket in case unexpected improvement
Putting more values into last bucket as time passes, we are still above 3,000 and we would need ~1.9% decrease every day which sounds quite unlikely.
Shifting slightly as we need declines of ~1.86% each day but in past few days, we've been going down slower.
Latest forecast day actually reported an increase in cases, and looking over past week it still seem that rate of hospitalization decrease is slowing down as well.

Leveling off. 3,132 as of 9/20.
If next two weeks’ decline looks like last two weeks, we are at roughly 2,756 on 10/4.
Updating with latest numbers, decrease in hospitalization has slowed.
updating based blending my belief with the crowd forecast
Cases have continued to rise. Hospitalizations ticked upward today.
Last 3 days of data has been on track to put us in the lower bucket so am bringing my probabilities back in a bit

Still declining, but very slowly. New cases in Texas seem to be plateauing[1], but even if those are mostly 20-39 year olds it will still mean some new hospitalizations. Starting to believe the number of hospitalizations will not go below 2500 for the foreseeable future, but stabilize a few hundred patients above it.  14 Sep-4 Oct: -40
>4 Oct: +40 1. https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/usa/texas/
581 down in 14 days? 43 decrease today. Staying with 50:50 and still regretting to ever have started this question...

In my last update I mentionned the decreasing rate should be 1.6% to reach 2500 on October 4th so for every day that has a lower rate I will decrease the 4th bucket of 2.7 (= 38% currently on this bucket / 14 remaining days, so 2 times 3% for 1 time 2% as we need to have rounded proba. Given the data of today I decrease 3%.

Hospitalizations began decreasing again over the past few days, so I'm de-extremizing a bit. Week over week cases continued to rise last week, but it is unclear how this will translate to hospitalizations (theoretically, the relationship depends on several factors we could maybe estimate, but data from earlier in the pandemic have not validated that theoretical relationship--the number of current hospitalizations, despite having low variance, is the most difficult metric to estimate.)

Considering high positivity rates (over 5%) and the fact that the curve is flattening (but not completely down trending) and current number around 3100, doubtful that they will decrease to less than 2500 in the next 14 days, but it is possible.
3124.  Holy cow. Will be very close.

I redid the calculations with this week's data and combined two outside views: (1) probability that the cases will fall below a certain level (related to bed occupancy) 7 days before the 4 of October, (2) probability that occupancy will be below 2500 before 4 of October. (1) gives me 95% and (2) gives be 57%, averaging: 76%
672 more needed on the way down, 16 days to go. 42 per day. This hasn´t got much to do with the numbers I expected it to be correlated to. Anyway: staying with 60:40 for bin 4.

The rate of decline has leveled off. From Sept 10th to 17th hospitalizations dropped by 329 or 47 cases per day. (3246 - 2500)/16 = 46.6 cases per day to drop below 2500. And the rate of decline seems to have been slowing a bit. I'm putting not before October 4th as the slight favorite.

My current forecas that i got from a model developped preivously lead me to assigne 40 for 14 sept - 4 october and 60 for after oct 4, as the plateau effect persists I will increase my last buckets of 2.5% percent every day (so 2-3 alternatively) until the end in 16 days.
Updating with new data and insights from my teammates (@ramasoma @walkertheos), as hospitalization decrease seems to have slowed down.
As mentioned by @dzhou3 , we would need ~1.6% down move every day to get to the 2,500 value which seems more and more unlikely, thus increasing the probability of last bucket.

The rate of cases declining is simply not enough to make it more likely to occur before 10/4. Additionally, cases in Dallas have started to increase, suggesting that Texas is not going to start plateauing dramatically quickly.
Model predictions on more data - aggressive flattening over the last week or so, and increase in cases.
updated model. My model predicts after oct 4 for both upper and lower bounds but keeping some weight in lower bucket in case recent standstill in counts is due to some temporary reason

Over the past few days the change in daily hospital cases seems to change in a more 'piece-wise.' We may have several days with essentially no change, and then a 3% change suddenly occurring. Also taking into account what @dzhou3  mentions in terms of average, we would have to realize a 1.6% average decrease in hospital cases between now and October to reach the 2500 boundary, which does seem on the higher end if we give more weight to recent changes. Finally it's important to note that new COVID cases in Texas seem to be flattening thus we might see hospitalization change rate to continue to be flat.  As a result, will adjust to having more weigh ton >Oct 4 bucket again.

In essence, we need about 1.6% decrease each day to make it to the October 4th deadline (16 days from today). Yesterday's decrease marginal (~0.09%). AR model from two days ago is also really pessimistic against prospects of reaching 2500 by October 4. Increasing probability of last bucket slightly. Premortem: Models are wrong (this is the big one upon second thought), the previous aforementioned premortems also hold.

Pace of declines may be slowing.
I have them on pace to be at about 2,467 on 10/4.

Aggressively updating forecast based on case data; cases are higher this week than last week. It seems like we have reached the plateau. However, hospitalizations could continue decreasing (for the reasons described in my last post).
Sticking my neck out a bit, to see what is over the edge.

Highest number of daily cases since Aug 25th - the benign trend seems reversed for now and I assume this will keep hospitalizations steady for several more weeks. https://covidtracking.com/data/state/texas/cases

Whether or not the hospitalizations in Texas will decline below 2,500 soon/before 04 October 2020 will depend on whether one assumes that the relatively stationary values of 12 to 15 September 2020 are a short hiatus in the decline/a transient outlier, or whether they are part of a new plateau which will be hard to come below, as some forecasters suggest. To me, it is an exponential decline, so for prediction/projection a linear approach does not lead to a correct conclusion. Instead, the reduction appears to follow a certain coefficient over time, but taking different reference periods leads to very different outcomes: Over the period of ten days between 06 and 16 September 2020, the number of hospitalizations has declined by 12.54%
Assuming this rate nearly constant over time, the projection, with a high weight (40% of the values) on the "transient outlier"-period, results the following approximation: 16 Sep 2020: 3,249
26 Sep 2020:  2,841est. [=h(TX 16 Sep 2020)*0.8746]
06 Oct 2020: 2,485est. [=h(TX 16 Sep 2020)*0.8746^2] The question would then be resolved on the fifth bin.

Another period (over the period of 19 days between 28 August and 16 September 2020, the number of hospitalizations has declined by 26.53%) with a lower weight on the "transient outlier"-period (21%), would lead to: 16 Sep 2020: 3,249
05 Oct 2020: 2,387 [=h(TX 16 Sep 2020)*0.7347]
The question would in this case likely be resolved on the fourth bin. I tend to believe in the latter case, and continue to pretend being comfortable with my current forecast for a few more days.

3249, so 749 above the limit. 62 down yesterday, but 4 days flat before that.
Tests and positivity rate look fine, so it looks like staying on course for bin 4.

Week over week cases have increased for three consecutive days. We could be reaching the plateau in cases. It's a little difficult to understand the impact of this on hospitalizations since the change in current hospitalizations can be very roughly approximately by new cases 1 week ago minus new cases 3 weeks ago--this means that hospitalizations often continue to decrease for about two weeks after cases plateau. This is tough, but I'm going to increase my post oct 4 probability a bit.  It's also worth noting that a lot of the prominent covid models are forecasting a plateau in the next week, probably because mobility has continued to increase over the past few weeks. That being said, these models are extremely unreliable.

10-day average of 46.6 less hospitalizations per day puts the 2,500 mark at October 3rd, remarkably close to the beginning of the final bucket. The 5-day average is down to 43.2 less per day (2,500 on October 5th), meaning the average is still decreasing since my last forecast just 4 days ago (September 27th and October 2nd, respectively). Looking at the actual plot, it is fairly easy to see that the hospitalizations are beginning to level out. The question now is whether the descent will continue at its current rate, speed up, slow down, or reverse. A complete reverse is unlikely in just a few weeks, as is an increase given current behaviors. Most likely, on average, the rate will continue to decrease in the next few weeks, which makes the final bucket the most likely. Random fluctuations and the potential for a sudden drop does leave a decent chance that the fourth bucket ends up winning.
Still counting on falling test-positivity to cause fewer hospitalizations but waiting to see what happens in the next few days. If I wasn't counting on this I would probably be 50:50.
Today is 3,311 with a reduction rate of  avg. 30.. that will take us to at least another 27 days. It could be in any of the 2 last brackets..

-10 to Sept to October. 18 days to go, the drop over the past 18 days (from August 29 to Sept 16) is 962. Currently at 3311. Assuming the same drop gets it to 2349. Just under 2500. But also the rate of decline may be leveling off. So I'm putting by October 4th as most likely but after October 4th is still very possible.
If average for last week continues it will make bin 4.

I give back some weights to after October 4 with the recent data.  In deed given the last 3 days plateau, it raises doubt that we can maintain an average 1.4% decrease (which the one needed to be at 2500 on October 4).  Re running my model with updated data i do get an expected rate at 1.9% so base rate is that we can reach 2500 before Oct 4. Howver, we cant assume a constant decrease rate (my model is super simple there) as it makes almost no doubt that  hospitalizations would plateau (and / or political decisions can change massively the slope( but the question is at which level: above or below 2500?  The different elements I took into account to assess this point:
- 'similar' states (population number is my metrics here, agree it is not perfect) evolution hospitalizations such as Florida one evolutions https://covidtracking.com/data/state/florida/hospitalization
- lagged positive cases, already mentionned in previous forecast how it is relevant https://covidtracking.com/data/state/texas/cases
- possible actions from Texas like lockdowns, social distancing measures
Flattening curve, recent case numbers realizing higher than the fitted model
Lowered weighting on the Sept 14th to Oct 4th buckets due to continued flattening of hospitalization decreases.

Moving back up on after 4 Oct given model EV is now early November. Decrease in hospitalizations has also stagnated in last few days, flattening around ~3300. Pre-mortem: Increased social distancing measures, lockdowns, vaccine pushed really early by Trump. Any other suggestions welcome.
Decrease rate has gone down a bit, making the Oct 4 more unlikely. Updating forecast on that.
Heavier weighting on the 9/14-10/4 bucket as the trend realizes.
Going down a little after the curve having been flat for 4 days in a row.
@WBHumanoid  has probably got it about right, but I'm biasing toward the crowd.
Hospital rates are no longer going down as quickly as I thought they would.
The 7-day moving average for daily hospital admissions/discharges is pretty jumpy — yesterday, it was -30. Today, it's -56.

Revising oct 4 up a bit because cases have continued to decrease linearly (they generally lead hospitalizations by ~5 days). This suggests that hospitalizations may continue to decrease close to linearly for the next week.

The fall in hospitalizations is plateauing — the 7-day moving average for daily hospital admissions/discharges is -30. At this rate, the number of hospitalizations will not fall below 2,500 before 4 Oct. However, hospitalizations only have to decrease by 42 per day to fall below 2,500 below 4 Oct.  This is a close call, but leaning toward this not happening before 4 Oct.
Updating using new data and the fact that one bucket now has probability 0.
continued decrease of hospitalizations despite reports of possible outbreaks in college towns - will increase bucket after October 4 if cases increase.
Based on the required rate to fall below 2500 by 10/4, adding a lot more mass to >10/4 and removing impossible buckets.

819 cases above 2500. 
Averaging three different approaches:
1) With an average number like yesterdays decrease (52, which was a little lower than the average of the week before) we would be at 2500 by 29 September with a linear approach. (80:20)
2) If we view it as asymtotic towards somewhere below 2500, it would take a little longer, which could indeed lead to bin 5. (60:40) 
3) If we look at the "big picture", it´s as discussed before: number of new infections is going down significantly, leading to less new hospitalizations. With the average person leaving hospital after 2-3 weeks it would be much faster, perhaps in a week already. On the other hand we need to consider the worst-case-possibility of numbers increasing again (20% for that), so it´s 80:20 for this approach).

Continue to increase the Between 14 September 2020 and 4 October 2020 bucket as the trend of hospitalizations is still down, no real plateau effect as of today. An additional point here is that the number of cases have continued to drop and hospitalizations tend to follow the same trend with lag of 7 days.

Revising my forecast up slightly. I've become more optimistic about the Texas hospitalization for two reasons: 1) cases have continued to drop over the past week (they tend to lead hospitalizations by 5-9 days); and 2) Florida, whose trajectory seems to have been a bit ahead of Texas for the past few months, has reduced hospitalizations more than I expected. I initially believed that hospitalizations would plateau at a higher level in Florida, Arizona, and Texas, but recent evidence from the former two states suggests that hospitalizations might continue decreasing at a strong pace.  That being said, I still think hospitalizations will eventually plateau; the question is whether they plateau at a number above or below 2,500. I'll be watching the infection data over the next week closely to determine whether and when the plateau might be coming. Mondays and Tuesdays often bring a backlog of cases from the weekend (and are more reliable than weekend data), so I plan to compare the numbers over the next two days to those a week ago.  Also, the University of Washington's covid model forecasts that hospitalizations will only decrease slightly, if at all, over the next few weeks. However, I'm also a bit skeptical of their predictions, which have been very unreliable in the past; it seems like it is basically impossible to model this stuff.

Updating out of Sept 13 bucket, next few days will be important to watch to see if we can get under 2500 by October 4. One thing to note is that active case numbers are starting to flatten out, which will be important to see how that affects hospitalizations.
hedging toward the crowd, but I suspect students have opened new vectors for spread which will unfortunately manifest in hospitalizations breaking the current downward count trajectory.

Shifting due to public opinion as well as quick back of the envelope math assuming 2% per day (2% came from average percent change since June) -> Sept 28th as EV. TS analysis is suggesting October 12 so splitting the diff gives exactly October 4. Will shift slightly hire towards 14 Sept - 4 Oct given public opinion.

I am averaging two outside views: (1) The exponential decrease in bed occupancy, which has slowed down and which would give me a 83% probability for bin 4 (17% for bin 5). (2) The exponential decrease in cases, assuming a delay for beds and a ratio, which gives me a 95% probability for bin 4 (5% for bin 5). Just check [1] for a more complete explanation. Obviously (1) does not need to be particularly reliable, as previous calculations gave me that the 3500 beds mark would be crossed on 4 of September, but this happened on the 11. Just as a reminder of [1]: Below 3500 beds: predicted 4 of September, happened 11 of September
Below 3000 beds: predicted 10-12 of September
Below 2750 beds: predicted 12-15 of September
Below 2500 beds: predicted 15-19 of September So just from the first delay it could be perfectly possible that I am underestimating the last bucket by miles. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1120902
This is similar to pricing a knock out option. We use a monte carlo simulation to predict the time of the process "stopping" or being "knocked out".
Actually looks like it's on a knife-edge, but I am relying on the big drop in test positivity resulting in fewer new hospitalizations in the coming weeks.
Quite steady downticks in the number of cases lately

Update september 13th: In the last month I observe a linear trend with a trend line formula of h(x) = -118*x + 6778 
where x is 0 on Aug 11th and h(x) is the number of hospitalizations in Texas on day x. If this trend continues the number of 2,500 COVID-19 Hospitalizations in the state of Texas for a single day will be hit between sept 17th and sept 21st. Therefore increasing the probability for the range between 14 September 2020 and 4 October 2020. A) There is a delay of 10 days (median value) between a detected infection and being hospitalized [1]. 
B) Test positivity rate in Texas is dropped from 19% 19 days ago to now 7% [2] 
C) The number of new hospitalizations per day dropped from 115 on 08/24/20 to 48 on 09/11/20.
There is an implicit correlation between B) and C) where B) is roughly shows how the rate of new hospitalizations will develop in 10 days (see A)).  Taking these facts together I think the probability that the rate of new hospitalizations increases suddenly in the next 10 days. if my model is correct we will hit the number of 2,500 COVID-19 Hospitalizations in less than 10 days. Current 10-day trend predicts the 2,500 mark to be reached in 15 days (September 27th). 5-day trend predicts it will be closer to 20 days (October 2nd). While both of these are before the final bucket, the disparity between the two suggests hospitalization decreases are shrinking each day. At this point, it's really a toss-up between the two options given all the unknowns surrounding the virus and how school and business reopenings and a potential fall resurgence will affect the hospitalization count moving forward.

Has to come down about 1000. It took about 2 weeks for that to reach current downturn.

Hospitalizations are decreasing by less than 100 per day, and the SEIR model suggests that the rate will slow significantly as the number of active hospitalizations decreases (theoretically cases should slow at a constant relative basis as opposed to a constant absolute basis).

Updated my rationale after team discussions. Ran a bootstrapped simulation (100000 sims) sampling from percentage change of hospitalizations since July 10th (1 week after mask ban was implemented). Starting off at current (9/9) cases, this gives me a 59/41 probability distribution for the first bucket (before Sept14).

How long will it take for another 1104 cases less? Looking at the curve it will be more than the 4 days required for bin 3. It just looks too asymptotic for that.
Seven day positivity rate went down from 16 to 8% in the past three weeks. With the number of tests quite stable that looks like a good sign to me. There should be significantly less new patients going to hospital and many of those still there leaving it in the near future (the average time in hospital in Germany was 2 weeks in July). Very much looks like it´s going to be bin 4, but with Covid-19 you never know. @ManuPV : In that case I agree with the time frame you mentioned.
Bin 5 can´t be ignored too. Perhaps there will be another wave or it´s asysmptotically (slowly) approaching a number above 2500. I don´t think so, because the baseline was below 2000 from April to June, but who knows? 25% for those scenarios.

Dean's models as a base prediction. With the small decrease in hospitalizations recently (500 in the last week), it seems possible that this will be a fat tail and take more than a month to hit 2,500 (possible increases in hospitalizations are also possible)
Not coming down very fast in recent days.

Although the number of hospitalizations is decreasing more slowly, the number of new cases is decreasing more quickly. Thus I would expect to see a precipitous decrease in bed occupancy in about 4-7 days. My favorite days for the closing of this question are between September 14 and 18. But I might be wrong, as the current reduction of cases might be an artifact.

My initial strategy was to take average daily percent increase over last 10 days and assume that rate will hold to determine when daily hospitalizations will dip under 2500. I also perturbed this rate up and down (by 1.2x and 0.8x) to get some CI (I thought at the time that this was something like a 90% CI but now I think it is lower.. maybe closer to 70% CI). Anyways, that gave me my prediction. I reran this analysis with the most recent data. My best estimate is 26 days from today (oct 4) and the CI is from Sep 30 to Oct 11. That leads me to my updated forecast. Also adding in a slight shift towards Not before Oct 4 in light of the hospitalization decrease rate decreasing in the last few days (this trend may continue).
Rationale explained in team discussion. Dean's prediction as an anchor, shifted down due increased confidence following recent decreases in hospitalizations.

Fitted new AR model, EV is 26 days from today which puts us at October 5, 2020. Since it is possible that cases spike, the distribution is fat-tailed, etc. we skew the probability a bit more in the favor of after 4 October 2020.

3,701 as of 9/7.

With the trend in the slowdown in hospitalizations it seems extremely likely that we get below 2500 active cases between now and October 4th. i have to leave in a fair amount of weight in the tail end, however, because of the possibility of a second wave of cases arising in between now and then that prevents this from happening. 13 Sept bucket is back as a possibility based on discharge rate.  If results for 8 Sept are as positive, will substantially increase the likelihood of the current bucket resolving.
Based on team & crowd consensus - adjusted more conservatively because school opening may exacerbate the spread of the coronavirus.

Hospitalizations decreased much more than I had originally expected this weekend, which is likely a result of the fact that total new Covid cases in Texas has been decreasing quite consistently. This was a factor that I had missed in my previous forecast and will now take more into account. I'm still quite surprised with this rapid decrease. Will definitely have to closely monitor over the next week.

Trends over the past week have been encouraging, and hospitalizations have declined by approximately 120 per day since my previous update. Although linearity should definitely not be the expectation, it seems much more likely that Texas reaches the 2500 mark within the next month, thus increased my probability of it taking place during the 14Sep - 4Oct bucket.

Given no policy or social distancing changes in Texas, our prediction could be reasonably modelled with a MC simulation of daily % decreases in hospitalizations that are assumed to be normally distributed (Texas hospitalizations have been steadily decreasing since July 28th, and new daily hospital admissions have been trending down since early July). Under such a simulation, it is predicted with 99.5% probability that the next time the daily number of hospitalizations will be 2500 or lower will be between Sep. 14 and Oct. 4. There is a 0.5% probability it will be after Oct. 4. However, there will be some policy shifts in the coming weeks that introduce more uncertainty into our model predictions. Schools and universities will be opening in-person for the fall term, with no current plans for widespread testing in public schools. In Quebec, Canada, where schools reopened one week earlier under a similar policy, we've already seen 50 schools with at least 1 positive COVID case (source: https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/covid-19-schools-quebec-list-1.5713145). How this will affect positivity and hospitalization rates is yet to be determined -- I'll be adding a 20% buffer to my predictions for now and updating my forecast accordingly over the next few weeks.
3537 today. Bin 3 back in the game a little. Bin 4 still main suspect.
The most recent several days of data were quite positive, with hospitalizations decreasing to around 3500. Thus, the chance of hitting 2500 sooner has increased

It is very difficult to tell at this time whether or not the hospitalizations are going to bottom out, or continue to decrease at the same rate (-2% per day) as they have over the past ~2 months. If they continue to decrease at that rate, it is almost certain that it will dip below 2,500 before Oct 4. If we are at the point where the percent change begins to flatten out then this is much less likely.  I attempted to model this uncertainty by first selecting a mean pct change from a uniform distribution with the 3 week mean as an upper bound and the 1 week mean as a lower bound. My logic for using the 3 week mean as an upper bound is that intuitively it seems like as the absolute number of cases falls, so too should the %change. For the lower bound the relatively1 week mean may represent a change in the trend of hospitalizations. With these parameters I conducted a 100000 monte carlo samples for the next 27 days to get probabilities for each case.  As more data comes available I expect that the distribution for the %change will become much more clear and the confidence of the prediction will become much higher.
Whatever the real data might be (top left says 3715, the main graph says 3796 for today) - it´s going down again. Adjusting accordingly.

Visually, we see that the hospitalizations in Texas is on a downward trend from a peak in July OF 10,892 Hospitalizations. As of writing, there were 3,973 hospitalizations on September 5th. Taking the last 20 data points , and using a simple linear regression model, the first time that hospitalizations drop below 2500 would be on September 14th. The rate of hospitalizations has decreased by 6600 over a month and a half. At this rate, we would see less than 2500 within 2 weeks. However, there is a lot of variance about this number, skewed towards the ‘upside’ (longer than 2 weeks). The graph of hospitalizations shows a slight flattening more recently in the trend. Given the trend doesn’t continue, I think the number of hospitalizations may continue to be above 2500 for quite a while; even before cases spiked in Texas, hospitalizations averaged around 1700 for several months. This number serves as a level of ‘irreducible’ hospitalizations that are simply too hard/expensive to control. 2500 is not much higher than this ‘irreducible’ level, again increasing the size of that right tail. California has had a similar (https://update.covid19.ca.gov/) growth and decline, and seems to be getting close to the ‘irreducible’ level with no sign of slowing down.

I exported the hospitalization data for New York and found that the log of hospitalization numbers declines linearly with time. Using New York as an analog, Texas will fall below 2500 on Sep 25th. However, Texas does not have any nearly as much intervention as New York, so  Sep 25th is a more optimistic estimation. Using Texas' own data, the first day below 2500 is Oct 24th. Thus, the baseline probability of the bin "Between 14 September 2020 and 4 October 2020" is approximately 10/30 = 33%, and the baseline probability of "Not before 4 October 2020" is then 67%.

The main difficulty of this problem comes with the fatness of the tails. Will take a more in depth look at this problem tomorrow, but for this projection I simply looked at the % decrease in hospitalizations over the last two weeks. Average decline over the past 2 weeks has been -2.6% a day, however over the past week we have only averaged a -1.4% decline per day. Again, because the tails are fatter this -1.4% decline seems to be a more likely rate, and potentially even something less than that (as declining rates have been even smaller in the past few days.  First, we can note that in order to reach 2500 cases by 9/13 we'd need to see a 4.75% decrease in hospitalizations each day, which is extraordinarily unlikely.  Next, using a 1.4% decline as a benchmark for decrease in hospitalizations a day, we see that it will take ~35 days for us to reach the 2500 mark. As the rate of decrease in hospitalizations seems to be flattening, this seems like a relatively safe baseline to have.  It is important to note that the number of daily coronavirus cases has dropped by  nearly half since the peak in early August so we could potentially see number of hospitalizations to drop quickly soon as well. If we look at the total number of active cases in Texas it is rapidly on its way down, which suggests we should put some more weight in the 9/14-10/4 bucket. Baseline: To create our baseline we read in the data and looked at how the hospitalization trends have developed so far and if there are predictors that can be used as leading indicators. We see that using an AR (autoregressive) model, we can use  the number of positive test cases as a leading indicator to see what the hospitalization rates will look like in the future. We see that values are lagging by 7-10 days, which is in line with CDC guidelines regarding the virus. Furthermore, we also modeled with a Monte Carlo simulation using the previous log growth values and a normal distribution for the decreases from historical values. Adjustments:
Comparables: We can look at other countries (states) that had a rapid spike in the number of cases and try to isolate the effect of different measures on the total number of cases and hospitalizations. We looked into New Jersey, New York and other European countries (Italy, Spain, France) to see how different measures affected the figures aforementioned. We need to, however, also account for the fact that Texas already had a lockdown (and is not likely to go into another one) and was late to implement any mandatory mask regulations (happened beginning of July). The figures show a fast decrease in the number of cases, but they also show that after some time the numbers just plateau and it decreases very slowly after that. The 2,500 cutoff is definitely in the range that falls into the gradual decrease, which makes prediction more difficult. Conclusion: Using the two simulation strategies and the adjustments due to different regulatory implementations, we come up with the distribution aforementioned.

I fitted an AR(17) model after testing for autocorrelation. The EV is Sept 30, 2020 based on my model. However, given the asymptotic behavior of the number of hospitalizations, the fact that my EV is closer to October 4 than September 13 and the fact that COVID cases could spike back up with the coming on fall/winter and the reopening of the economy, I put more weight on after October 4, 2020 then between August 24, 2020 - September 13, 2020.

I used data since the number of hospitalizations in Texas started to drop in mid-July, because I don't think the kind of wave that occurred before that is likely to occur again before October 4. Specifically I used the most recent 50 data points. I then ran two Monte Carlo simulations. The sampled from percent changes in the hospitalization numbers, whereas the second sampled from arithmetic changes. I averaged these numbers to obtain the final result. Empirically I noticed that the drop in hospitalizations seemed to have flatten over the past few days. Because of this, on each iteration of the simulations, I had the program randomly choose between no change and a change sampled from the above distributions. While a random simulation approach is not always warranted, I felt it was justified here because COVID is so unpredictable. I also felt that Texas has had a unique approach towards COVID, so it wouldn't be accurate to compare it to the trends other states have had.

I have analysed the data once again, and here it is what I found: 1) Bed occupancy is decaying by a weekly factor x_beds = 0.806 +/- 0.014, which puts the probability of being below 2500 beds before the 13 of September at 0.013% If the trend is reliable, I find about a 54% probability of getting below 2500 beds between 14 and 17 of September (included), and about a 99% probability that it happens before 21 of September. 2) Cases: this has been a curious issue, because we have seen a continuous decrease in the proportion of cases which end up in bed occupancy, where there is a really good comment by @Dillyweed here [1]. However I think I have found the cause: it is the delay between testing and results. 2.a) There is a strong correlation between hospital beds at day N and the number of total weekly cases from day N-offset: Beds(day_n) = factor * (Total_cases(day_n - offset) - Total_cases(day_n - offset -7) ) 2.b) From the NY hospitalization data, offset = 9 worked really well if we wanted to obtain a stable factor. This factor stabilized at about 0.13-0.14 for Texas during mid-July. 2.c) But since them, this factor has been steadily going down, till 0.08 to 0.09 today. And this was totally destabilizing the probabilities. 2.d) However then I thought about the delay in test results, which indicate that the offset needs to be smaller. With offset = 6 or 7, we get again a factor = 0.10 to 0.11 that is stable in time (instead of steadily decreasing in time). 2.e) Redoing the calculation, now we will need the number of weekly cases on the 6 or 7 of September to be below (23-25) K per week. Right now is 34K per week, which requires a geometric decrease below 0.74 within one week. This could happen, but it is not particularly likely, as the geometric decrease factor seems to be hovering around 0.9. But it could happen. However it is more probably a signal to look for than a factor that should change current probabilities. 3) Finally, there could be a change of trend in cases, which will ruin the decrease in hospitalizations. Thus I have included some probability in the "Not before 4 October" bucket. 4) For cross-checking my own results (most probable dates): Below 3500 beds: 4 of September
Below 3000 beds: 10-12 of September
Below 2750 beds: 12-15 of September
Below 2500 beds: 15-19 of September If any of these milestones is crossed before the expected date, I should really panic and correct my current predictions. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1113540

New update, with two contradicting set of probabilities. Let me explain: 1) Bed occupancy evolution: in this case I model the following: Beds(today) = x Beds(today - 7 days) which follows a nice exponential decay pattern. Then I calculate x_mu and x_sigma (the median and the variance) during the last 7, 14 and 21 days, which gives me: x(last 7 days) = 0.837 +/- 0.015
x(last 14 days) = 0.839 +/- 0.017
x(last 21 days) = 0.854 +/- 0.029 which are basically compatible at the statistical level (maybe with the exception of the one for the last 21 days). I compare this with the type of exponential decay required for getting 2500 beds on 14 September and 4 October, respectively: x_14Sep = 0.789
x_04Oct = 0.883 This gives me {0, 0, 1, 84, 15} for the buckets if I used the mean and variance of the last 3 weeks (which has the largest variance). If I use the other two values (previous 1 and 2 weeks), then the probabilities will peak close to 100% in the 14 September to 4 October bucket. 2) New weekly cases: previously, from the NYC hospitalization data [1], it was apparent that there is a strong correlation between total beds occupied and new weekly cases (with a certain offset), i.e. Bed_occupancy (today) = fac * (total_cases(today-offset)  - total_cases(today-offset-7)) where for TX, the factor fac has moved between 0.10 and 0.14 and the best offset seems to be 9. At the same time, the new weekly cases also follows a nice exponential behavior: (total_cases(today-offset)  - total_cases(today-offset-7)) = x_cas * (total_cases(today-offset-7)  - total_cases(today-offset-14)) with x_cas calculable as in the previous cases, giving the following means and variances: x_cas (last 7 days / w offset = 9) = 0.962 +/- 0.051
x_cas (last 14 days / w offset = 9) = 0.955 +/- 0.054
x_cas (last 21 days / w offset = 9) = 0.933 +/- 0.060 which is however incompatible with the hospitalization data, though the incompatibility is systematic (basically fac is decreasing with time). This anomalous behavior was noted by @Dillyweed in previous posts. With this, and fac = 0.09 and 0.10 respectively, the buckets are filled as {0,0,0,26,74} and {0,0,0,17,83}, indicating a much larger probability of the last bucket. I will simply average to {0,0,0,21,79} 3) Now the problem is how to combine 1+2. What I have done is give a weight of 0.75 to view 1, and 0.25 to view 2, resulting in my current prediction. That is, I have considered that the behavior of hospitalizations is more fundamental in the time frame of the question than the behavior of the pandemic in Texas. This choice is based on the experience of a previous question about the hospitalization in AZ, but it could be a bad choice. In fact it could be the weak link for my answer to this question: it might very well happen that the key point still is the reduction of the new cases, rather than bed policies. I have been crunching the numbers once more, and tried the two approaches that @Dillyweed is also trying: 1) Bed occupancy by itself: right now we have 6632 occupied bed, which follow a relatively regular decay pattern. Thus the number of bed occupied in the future is: Beds(n_weeks) = 6632 x^{n_weeks} For being below 2500 by 14 September, we need x < 0.796, for 4 October x < 0.872. The decay since the peak has been in between 0.88-0.92, except for the last few days in which it has suddenly dropped to 0.82-0.84. So not sure which of the two buckets. 2) Bed occupancy as a function of new weekly cases: here the best predictor I could find both from NY and TX hospitalizations is that the total number of beds occupied correlates really well with the number of new weekly cases 9 days before. That is: Bed(today) = f * (TotalCases(today - 9 days ) - TotalCases(today- 16 days)) for TX, f has been relatively stable at 0.14 till a few days ago in which it has dropped to f = 0.12 (well, the problem with the sudden recent drop in occupancy). The number of weekly cases follows a relatively stable exponential fall lately: TotalCases(today) - TotalCases(today - 7) = y (TotalCases(today - 7) - TotalCases(today - 14)) with y somewhere around 0.9 on average. From this we can compute how quickly do we need the number of weekly cases to fall for both f = 0.12 and f = 0.14: 2.a) f=0.12, we need y < 0.726 for Sept 14 and y < 0.849 for Oct 4
2.b) f=0.14, we need y < 0.689 for Sept 14 and y < 0.827 for Oct 4 Both 2.a) and 2b) make it almost impossible for this question to be solved before Sept 14, and relatively unlikely for Oct 4, as it requires a decline of the number of cases considerably faster than what we are seeing. However the latest few days for 1) suggest that it might be possible for occupancy to drop faster (the second last bucket instead of the last one). But on the other hand it could be a fluke.

Hospitalizations today were recorded at 7,216 with a downward linear trend around 183 people per day. If this trend holds, it would take 26 days to pass 2,500 hospitalizations per day, which puts us at September 6th. However, consistent linear trends are rare in epidemiology, both on the way up and on the way down. More likely, the slope will decrease in magnitude in the coming weeks (even if a second wave does not begin). This drop in magnitude will likely push the 2,500 benchmark back by several days, putting an expected date closer to the September 14th range. A lot could happen between now and then, but at least at the moment, I'd say there is a good chance we won't see less than 2500 hospitalizations in a single day in Texas until mid- to late-September.

Based on current trends for COVID-19 related hospitalizations that we are seeing for the State of Texas, I would imagine that once the lagging death counts that have fallen behind the most recent COVID-19 related hospitalization surge from the Memorial Day weekend catches up - not to mention a potential surge that could still come resultant from July 4 gatherings - we will see a more galvanized public toward ensuring proper mask use and social distancing guidelines being followed. However, it may take another week or so before these trends really become pronounced enough to elevate this issue above the partisan rhetoric in order to make it to the general public. These values are my best estimate based on the data available at this moment, and they can be interpreted as a reflection in the sentiment that I personally feel that this issue will get much worse before it gets better due to many factors that have persisted for far too long in my home State of Texas, with lagging mask use being one of the primary reasons along with the failure of state leaders to set an appropriate tone as to the seriousness of this pandemic.  Both trends for COVID-19 related deaths and hospitalizations have trended upward since Memorial Day(prior to this they were flat), and as I believe monitoring how local healthcare systems are being impacted is a much more relevant indicator as to this viruses presence in our community - due to its ability to overwhelm those systems being of paramount concern as that is the primary threat it presents - it would then be reasonable to expect continued upward trends to create a much lower threshold at which we could adequately address and contain larger outbreaks so as to prevent "super clusters" of infected individuals from appearing in likely regions (e.g., Houston, San Antonio, Dallas).  It will be interesting to see if a surge similar to the one that occurred after Memorial Day/Mass protests (not sure how much protests may have impacted Texas) will happen due to the July 4th holiday; If the R0 factor is truly around 2.5 (as CDC best estimates), and if the most recent surge was due to the gatherings occurring after restrictions eased, then the surge that could theoretically happen in the next week or so could see COVID-19 related hospitalizations rise to the 15,000 to 17,000 range by the end of August. This scenario would more than likely prompt the Texas State Government to take drastic and swift action to prevent the local healthcare systems from being overwhelmed in both the short-term (being 3-months) and long-term (being 9-12-months) due to the strength this virus will most likely gain as winter months bring with them an increase in immunosuppressed populations as well, being Vitamin D levels have been demonstrated as being strongly correlated with worst outcome scenarios for COVID-19 patients in ICU's from other countries suffering from this pandemic (Alipio, 2020). I have been playing with the data from NYC, which can be found here https://github.com/thecityny/covid-19-nyc-data and tried to find a few patterns. The most important pattern is that the new weekly cases at day n-9 are a very good predictor of Covid-19 beds at day n, though the offset 9 is not necessarily exact. It could be 8 or 10 days, or something similar. In short: Cases (n-offset) - Cases(n-offset-7) = factor * Hospitalization (n) with offset around 9. For Texas this also seems to be true. During the growing phase, the 2500 hospitalizations mark happened on the 16 of June, which indicates that we should look at the increase in cases between 7 of June and 31 of May, a bit less than 11K cases. This suggest that covid-19 hospitalizations will go below the 2500 mark about 9 days after there are less than 11K cases in a week, though this last number might have to be larger is there is increased testing, maybe 14K cases. Yesterday the weekly new cases were about 68K and 79 days away 4 of October. If we want to have less than 14K cases 9 days before that deadline, we have to reduce the weekly number of cases by a factor of 0.85 per week to reach the mark. If we use the original 11K as a better mark, the weekly reduction has to be by a factor of 0.83. After the first peak, the weekly reduction of deaths (not cases) in the US was about 0.86-0.88 per week, with a daily variance of 0.06-0.08. If I use this as a proxy of future reduction of cases, we are about half a sigma away from having less than 11-14K cases. But this is assuming that the daily variance of the weekly decrease can be used as a variance of what will happen in the following 10 weeks. And this is not the case: the variance along a longer period of time is actually smaller. Besides, we do not know whether Texas would be able to reach that level of reduction: it might happen that they are able to reduce it at the rate of the European countries (0.65-0.80 reduction per week), or it might happen that they will barely able to reach a 0.9 weekly reduction. Not to mention that this is a period of 10 weeks: any social distancing measure (bar a full two months and a half lockdown) will quickly run into social distancing fatigue, which will imply the impossibility of reaching the required level to be below 2500 hospitalizations. This means that my forecast right now is optimistic. However in just a pair of weeks it will be possible to determine with a very high degree of confidence whether we should go to 100% in the "Not before 4 October 2020" bucket. Looking at some other states who have been successful in tamping down COVID-19 (i.e., specifically NYS, although I have been following other countries such as Greece - success story -, Brazil, Italy, Spain, UK), the slope of the increase in positive cases as well as hospitalization hits its peak very quickly.  In NYS, the first case was identified on 2/29/2020, and the peak of cases hit on 4/10/2020, roughly one month.  After that, new cases declined very very slowly (and are continuing to decrease very slowly through today, July 15).  The rate of positive cases is sort of a thermometer into looking at all other statistics - hospitalizations, deaths, and recoveries are all contingent and positively correlated with +cases.  While you can't always tell how many deaths or hospitalizations you will have, the slope of the +cases trajectory will be mimicked by other statistics.  So the patterns of +cases (initial rapid increase followed by a gentler declining slope) is imitated by other stats. Now in the areas where there were significant quarantines (Italy, Greece) or stay-put orders with teeth (ie, NYS - high fines for violations, etc.), the general heuristic is that it takes roughly 100ish days or so for any of the rates to get near or close to 0.  If you look at the peak of NYS, which was 4/10 --> 7/13 (the first day without any COVID-19 related deaths), that is about 94 days.  Hospitalizations usually lag about a week or two behind +cases and deaths. However, the great state of Texas is not quarantining nor are they imposing teeth on their stay-put orders (at least not what I have seen as of today 7/15/2020).  My strong feeling that the first time we will see a decrease will be in November 2020, although there is a small probability that we might see a decrease between 9/14 and 10/4 (7/15--> 10/4 is 79 days, just under the 100ish mark, but we don't have any confidence intervals for that - remember it's just a heuristic). My goal is to look over the trajectories for other illnesses (e.g., avian flu, swine flu, etc.), and possibly update the predictions.   Curious to hear your thoughts.

I used NY as my comparison point for hospitalization rise in Texas, but I don't think it's well-suited as a comparison for hospitalization fall: the NY lockdowns were quite stringent, compliance was high, personal behavior was largely in line with health recommendations, and the government response was very well-regarded. None of those are/will be true of Texas.  Instead, I'm looking at California and Illinois as comparisons. California is obviously a bad-case scenario - the outbreak never quite came under control statewide and is now worsening again. Illinois is my good-case scenario, with slightly less than half the population size of Texas and a hospitalization peak that's slightly less than half of where hospitalizations are in Texas right now. It's not an optimistic good-case scenario. It took about two months for Illinois hospitalizations to drop to 1/4 of the peak, and they barely made it there and are now showing signs of worsening again. On top of that, their lockdowns/compliance were likely better than Texas's will be, and I don't think Texas hospitalizations have actually peaked.  Looking at the broader view, so many states continue to struggle with backsliding regardless of how good their responses were, and public will for containment/mitigation measures seems to be slowly but steadily waning. I think it's unlikely that any of the current bad outbreaks will drop at the rate of the first bad outbreaks.  When Texas hospitalizations actually peak and what Texas schools end up doing will be big data points.
